result.execSummary:
The defendant Tallie Jean Strommen was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Neglecting a Child (Consequence is Death), a class D felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.21(1)(d).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: $268 DOC Collect within 6 months from Release from Prison.   If Extended Supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Must Obtain and/or Maintain Full-Time Employment and/or School
Any assessment/treatment/counseling deemed necessary and follow through with any recommended treatment.

Absolute Sobriety to include NO Purchase, Possession or Consumption of Alcohol or Controlled Substances until Prescribed by a physician and then only according to physician's orders.
Deft is NOT to be in the company of any person who is using, purchasing or possessing illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.

records.addlTxt: Defendant Tallie Jean Strommen in court in custody with attorney Richard L. Jones.  David Jon O'Leary appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court orders: 10 years bifurcated sentence: 5 years WSPrison, 5 years Extended Supervision; w/Conditions: Pay costs within 6 months of release from Prison., Absolute Sobriety, No Alcohol or Controlled Substance, Must Maintain Full-Time Employment or School, AODA, Anytreatment or Cousneling, Mental Health Treatment or Counseling; Deft is Not Eligible for Challenge Incarceratipn ORgram, Deft IS NOT Eligible for Substance Abuse Program; 384 days credit.
